journal-meta.journal-title: Vision: The Journal of Business Perspective

title-group.article-title: Robustness of Fama-French Three Factor Model: Further Evidence for Indian Stock Market

bio.p: Sanjay Sehgal (sanjayfin15@gmail.com) is Professor of Finance at the Department of Financial Studies in Delhi University. He teaches Security Analysis and Portfolio Management, Equity Research and Econometrics. He did Post Doctoral Research on ‘Multi Factor Asset Pricing’ from the Department of Accounting and Finance, London School of Economics (UK). He has completed three government funded research projects and wrote a book besides contributing several research papers in the reputed national and international journals. He is on the Editorial Board of the leading Finance journals and is a member of the SEBI Committee on Investor Education and Protection. He is currently researching in the area of Investment Management, Derivatives and Corporate Finance.

Balakrishnan A. (abalki22@gmail.com) is Assistant Professor in the Department of Banking Technology at Pondicherry University. He teaches Investment and Portfolio Management, Accounting and Financial Analysis, Treasury and Derivatives Management, Financial Statement Analysis Using SPSS to MBA (Banking Technology) students. He is researching in the area of Investment Management and Derivatives and Corporate Finance.

abstract.p: In this article, we re-examine the efficacy of one factor capital asset pricing model (CAPM) and Fama-French three factor asset pricing model (FF model) in explaining the returns on various portfolios constructed based upon company characteristics such as size and value. Data is employed from 1996 to 2010 for 465 companies which form part of BSE-500 index. We use the same methodological procedures of Fama-French (1993 and 1996) for constructing the portfolios. This article evaluates the robustness of FF model with its standard version (Market Capitalization–Price to Book ratio) as well as alternative versions. We find that FF model does a better job than CAPM by explaining the returns on most of the portfolios constructed based on company characteristics. We also find that the alternative versions of FF model are robust in explaining the returns on various characteristics sorted portfolios.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Until recent past, Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM) developed by Sharpe (1964), Lintner (1965) and Black et al. (1972) was a strong model being used by the market practitioners to quantify the relationship between risk and return on equity stock. The core prediction of the model is that the market portfolio of invested wealth is mean-variance efficient in the opinion of Markowitz (1959). The Sharpe-Lintner-Black (SLB) model started losing its grounds due to the empirical contradictions, predominantly asset pricing anomalies which emerged from many empirical works experimented in various stock markets across the world. Asset pricing anomalies include company characteristics such as company size effect documented by Banz (1981). The value effect is recorded by Chan et al. (1991) and Basu’s (1977) price to earnings ratio effect. Bhandari (1988) records leverage and average returns on stock have positive relation.

Stattman (1980), Rosenberg et al. (1985) show for the US market that average stock returns are positively related with book equity to market equity ratio (BE/ME). Fama-French (1993) develop a three factor model comprising of CAPM based market factor and two additional risk factors such as company size (measured by market capitalization) and value (measured by Book Equity to Market Equity). Fama-French (1996) document that their multifactor model can explain most of the CAPM anomalies and hence provide an alternative asset pricing tool for market practitioners. They also exhibit that cross section of average stock returns could be well explained by their model even when one uses alternative proxies for the size and value factor.1 Fama-French (2008) report some new anomalies such as net stock issues, accruals, momentum, asset growth and profitability. They also find that average stock returns are associated with first three anomalies while asset growth and profitability are found to be less robust.

There is growing empirical evidence in favour of the three factor model for other world markets, besides USA (see Fama-French, 1998). In Indian context, Connon and Sehgal (2003) provide empirical evidence in favour of the Fama-French three factor model.

In this article we re-examine the relation between average returns and firm characteristics (size, value and their alternative measures). We also re-experiment Fama-French model (FF model) for the Indian environment by performing out of sample test using data for a longer time period (1996 to 2010) including a more recent study period. Such a study will enable us to verify if the Fama-French factors are valid over time and hence not an outcome of investor fancies for certain company characteristics which fade away with the passage of time. We inter alia examine the robustness of FF model with regard to alternative construction/selection of risk factors.

The article is organized as follows. In the second section, we describe data and their sources. In the third section we evaluate if the Fama-French three factor model is a better descriptor of asset returns compared to one factor CAPM. In the fourth section, we verify if asset pricing results are robust to alternative construction/selection of Fama-French risk factors. Concluding remarks are given in the final section.

sec.title: Data
sec.p: The data comprises month end adjusted share prices2 for 465 companies from January 1996 to December 2010. The sample companies form part of Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) 500, a broad based stock market index which covers more than 17 sectors and contains the companies of varying levels of size and trading activity. The sample companies account for more than 90 per cent of market capitalization and daily trading volume in India, hence they are fairly representative of market performance. The share price data has been obtained from CMIE PROWESS, a provider of financial statement related information for Indian companies. The monthly share prices for estimation and further analysis purposes have been converted into percentage monthly return series. The returns are computed using only the capital gain component. The dividend component has been consciously ignored on account of the fact that Indian companies have very low dividend yield (Gupta, 2000). Further dividend is declared annually in corporate India and hence its monthly value on estimation would be small and arbitrary. Also, the market index returns against which portfolio returns will be regressed later and do not incorporate dividends. Hence inclusion of dividends in stock returns will introduce bias in our estimation procedure.

Stylized portfolios are formed on the basis of company characteristics such as firm size and value. Three measures of company size namely market capitalization ([MC] price time number of shares outstanding), total assets (TA) and enterprise value (EV) are employed. The last measure mentioned above is more relevant from the perspective of corporate and institutional investors who may value a company as potential acquisition target in light of spurt in mergers and takeover activities in Indian market.

Fama-French (1993, 1996) suggest a relative distress (also known as value) factor consistent with Merton’s (1973) ICAPM framework. The relative distress factor implies that companies with low price-to-book equity (P/B) and price-to-earning (P/E) ratios and past sales growth (PSG) have persistently low earnings and therefore should provide higher returns to the investors. The companies with high P/B and P/E ratios and PSG have persistently high earnings and therefore generally provide lower returns to the investors. Following the previous research, we use P/B, P/E and PSG as value measures. The data source for company characteristics is again obtained from CMIE PROWESS. Enterprise value is not directly available and hence it is computed by combining the book value of debt with market value of equity information. Past sales growth (PSG) has been calculated using three year compounded value of net sales prior to portfolio formation.

The implicit yields on 91-day treasury bills (T-bills) have been used as risk free proxy, as has been the common practice in investment management research. The data has been taken from the website of Reserve Bank of India (RBI). The BSE national index (1983–1984) has been used as surrogate for aggregate economic wealth. The BSE national index is a broad based value weighted index which is constructed on the lines of Standard & Poor-500, USA.

sec.title: Explanatory Power of One Factor CAPM and Three Factor Fama-French Model
Methodology
sec.p: Double sorted portfolios based on ranking of sample securities on two company characteristics, i.e., size and value using the following procedure. Following the previous research, we use MC, TA and EV as size measures and P/B ratio, P/E ratio and PSG as value measures for ranking the sample securities. In June of year (t) the sample stocks are ranked on the basis of size (measured as MC). They are then classified into two groups, i.e., small (S) bottom 50 per cent and big (B) top 50 per cent. The sample stocks are also classified into three groups, i.e., low (L) bottom 33.33 per cent, medium (M) 33.33 per cent to 66.66 per cent and high (H) above 66.66 per cent based on P/B ratio in March of year (t). We construct six portfolios having S/L, S/M, S/H, B/L, B/M and B/H from the intersection (MC-PB) of two market capitalization and three price to book groups. The S/L portfolio contains small and relatively more distressed stock, while B/H consists of big and relatively less distressed stock. The monthly equally weighted excess returns on these six portfolios are computed from July 1996 (t) to June 1997 (t+1). The revised rankings are done in June 1997 and the entire portfolio formation process is repeated up to December 2010. The mean excess return3 on each portfolio is computed from July 1996 to December 2010. We replicate the portfolio formation methods for alternative measures of company size and value, i.e., TA, EV (size measure), PE ratio and PSG (value measure) and form 54 portfolios from nine combinations, i.e., MC-PB, MC-PE, MC-PSG, TA-PB, TA-PE, TA-PSG, EV-PB, EV-PE and EV-PSG. Since TA is fully and EV is partly accounting based size measure, their information is available in March of each year which happens to be the financial closing month in India. Given the fact that some companies’ overtime may have delayed the release of financial information, there may be a lag between the financial closing date and the time when investors can use this information for decision making purpose. We form portfolios with three month gap from financial closing date to account for this problem.

sec.title: Risk Proxy Construction Procedure
sec.p:
The portfolio small minus big (SMB) is meant to mimick the risk factor in return relating to size. SMB is the difference between the simple average of the returns on the three small-stock portfolios and the simple average of the returns on the three big-stock portfolios. It is expressed in the form of:
(1) SMB = (((S/L) + (S/M) + (S/H)) – ((B/L) + (B/M) + (B/H)))/3

The portfolio low minus high (LMH) is meant to mimick the risk factor in return relating to value and LMH is the difference between the simple average of the returns on the two high—P/B portfolios (S/H and B/H) and the average returns on the two low P/B portfolios (S/L and B/L). LMH is expressed in the way of:
(2) LMH = (((S/L) + (B/L) – ((S/H) + (B/H)))/2
Both SMB and LMH factors are expected to be orthogonal by construction.

The monthly excess returns on each portfolio are regressed on excess returns for the market factor over the estimation period as proposed by CAPM, by using the familiar excess return version of the market model as shown below.
where
RPt – RFt = Excess returns on portfolio,
RMt – RFt = Excess returns on the market factor,
a = Measure of abnormal returns and
b = Sensitivity coefficient.
Equation (3) is estimated under the assumption that the market model can be used to empirically evaluate the CAPM specification.

Then, the excess returns on sample portfolios are regressed on returns for market, size and value factors using the Fama-French three factor model which is expressed in the form of:
(4) RPt – RFt = a + b RMt – RFt + s SMBt + l LMHt + et
where,
SMB and LMH represent size and value factors and
S and l are the sensitivity coefficients of SMB and LMH factors respectively.

sec.title: Empirical Results
sec.p: Table 1 Panel A provides mean excess returns on portfolios sorted on the basis of company size and value. It shows that all S/L portfolios outperform B/H portfolios except EV-PSG portfolio. Further the mean excess return differential between portfolios S/L and B/H is more than 30 per cent on annualized basis in all cases except TA-PSG and EV-PSG. This suggests that there is a strong size and value effect. The return differential between small size and value4 stocks and big size growth5 stocks confirm that there is a strong size effect in the Indian market. Our findings contradict to Berk’s argument6 for the US market who proves that size effect is tautological in nature.

We show that size effect is equally strong using both market as well as non-market size measures. Unlike Berk (1996) who finds that size return relationship is absent for the non-marketable size measures. Next, we evaluate if size and value pattern in stock returns can be explained by competing asset pricing models.

The return differentials appear to be too large so as to be explained by rational risk premia. It is very important to find out if any of these excess returns provided by size and value sorted portfolios can be explained by risk factors.

Table 1 Panel B reports risk adjusted abnormal returns on the sample portfolios using CAPM as an asset pricing benchmark. If the excess return version of market model is the best way to estimate CAPM, then alphas (intercept) shall be close to zero. It is clearly observed that CAPM fails to absorb excess returns on S/L stock portfolios which is reflected by significant t-statistics (at 5 per cent level) for the alphas of these portfolios. These results are similar for all S/L stocks of different size/value measures other than TA-PSG and EV-PSG. There is very little difference between the betas of S/L and B/H thus indicating why CAPM is not able to capture the extra normal returns.

Table 1 Panel C presents regression results using FF model. The FF model is able to explain major part of abnormal returns on S/L portfolio. This is possible because S/L portfolio loads more heavily on the size and value factors compared to B/H portfolio.

caption.p: Panel A: Mean Excess Returns on Double Sorted Portfolios

tr.td: Panel B: CAPM Results for Double Sorted Portfolios RPt – RF t= a + b (RMt – RFt) + et
Panel C: CAPM Fama-French Model Results RPt – RF t= a + b (RMt – RFt) + s SMBt + l LMHt+et

sec.title: Alternative Construction/Selection of Fama-French Factors
sec.p: In this section, we examine if the FF model for characteristic sorted portfolios are robust to alternative construction/selection of risk factors. In Fama-French original works (1993) the size and value factors are constructed using MC and P/B measures respectively. We construct size (SMB) and value (LMH) proxies using three size measures (MC, TA and EV) and three value measures (P/B and P/E and PSG). Hence we have nine different combinations of size and value proxies (including the MC_PB formation) resulting in nine versions of the FF model.

Table 2 exhibits alternative versions of FF model and provide equally strong results. The mean absolute alphas (measure of abnormal returns) as well as adjusted R2 (measure of goodness of fit) are almost similar across these versions. Further, the FF model (with alternative size and value proxies) seems to outperform CAPM as latter has the substantially high mean absolute alpha.

caption.p: Double Sorted Portfolios Formed on Different Measures of Company Size and Value: Comparative Results of CAPM and Fama-French Model

sec.title: Summary and Concluding Remarks
sec.p: In this article we evaluate alternative asset pricing models for their ability to explain cross section of average stock returns. Data is employed for 465 most active companies from 1996 to 2010 for India, an emerging market. We form the portfolios using double sort criterion based on size/value. We use three measures of company size, i.e., market capitalization (MC), total assets (TA) and enterprise value (EV) and standard measures of corporate value, i.e., P/B and PE ratios and PSG.

We confirm the presence of strong size and value effects in Indian stock market. FF three factor model is proved to be a better descriptor of returns on company characteristic sorted portfolios compared to one factor CAPM. However, the FF model does not fully explain the abnormal returns missed by CAPM as t values for 7 portfolios out of 54 are statistically significant. These results are in contrast with previous findings for the Indian environment documented by Connon and Sehgal (2003) and more consistent with global findings.

fn.p: Fama-French (1996) construct the value factor using alternative proxies such as P/B, P/E, price-to-cash flow and past sales growth, etc.
The share prices are adjusted for capitalization changes such as stock splits, stock dividends and right issues. This enables us to compare the price series over time.
The excess return for any period t is defined as the difference between security/portfolio return and risk free return for that time period.
Low P/B and P/E stocks are termed as value stocks (see Lakonishok et al., 1994).
High P/B and P/E stocks are termed as growth stocks (see Lakonishok et al., 1994).

Berk (1995, 1996) shows that size effect is a tautological result in US context. He proves by showing that there is negative relationship between firm size and return when one uses market capitalization as a size measure. These results may simply be an outcome of the nature of valuation equation. He further shows that there is no inverse relationship between size and return when one uses non-market based measures of company size such as total assets, fixed assets, number of employees, etc.
